Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Comment: “On occasion, a grammatically singular noun that refers to a group of sorts (e.g., калык [kɑlək] ‘people’, кӱтӱ [kyty] ‘herd’, еш [jeʃ] ‘family’), or pair nouns/collective nouns [...], co-occur with plural forms of verbs. In these cases, singular verbal forms are however also possible, and recommended by prescriptive grammarians.”

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with a nominal object?
Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: There is no case agreement within noun phrases at all.

Name: Is there non-agreement between an adnominal property word and the head noun?
Comment: There is no case agreement within noun phrases at all.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (S/A) marking?
Comment: “The gerunds in -мек(е) [-mek(e)] and -меш(ке) [-meʃ(ke)] take possessive suffixes; their agent, which can (but does not have to) differ from the agent of the superordinate (often finite) verb, can be marked by a preceding pronoun or noun. If the agent of the gerundial action is a noun, it can be in the nominative or the genitive. Inanimate nouns generally occur in the nominative, while animate nouns occur in either the nominative or genitive. When used with a genitive form, the gerund usually has a possessive suffix third person.” (Riese et al. 2019:254) The same applies to participles (EG 261, 265, 266); the picture is more complicated with postpositions (Riese et al. 2019:160) where the government depends on the individual postposition.

Name: Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of the object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Comment: Differential object marking can be attested only in non-finite clauses (Riese et al. 2019:70).

Name: Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does object marking depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Is there grammatical marking of habituality?
Comment: Compound past tenses I & II (formed by present-tense form followed by ‘to be’ in the third person singular, either in simple past I or II) are habitual (the distinction between them is evidential). Also, aspectual auxiliaries (light verbs) илаш ‘to live’ and шогалаш ‘to stand up’ can be coupled with a converb and give the resulting pairing a habitual value.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of frequentativity?
Comment: Numerous defivational suffixes, descending by their productivity: v-л [-l]: лӱмдаш [lymdɑʃ] ‘to name’ → лӱмдылаш [lymdəlɑʃ] ‘to call names’, -ешт [-eʃt]: колаш [kolɑʃ] ‘to hear’ → колышташ [koləʃtɑʃ] ‘to listen’, -кал [-kɑl]: ойыраш [ojərɑʃ] ‘to separate’ → ойыркалаш [ojərkɑlɑʃ] ‘to sort’, -ед [-ed]: пуаш [puɑʃ] ‘to give’ → пуэдаш [puedɑʃ] ‘to hand out’. Also auxiliary опташ ‘to place (several items)’.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of progressivity?
Comment: Aspectual auxiliary (light verb) илаш [ilɑʃ] ‘to live’ is used.

Name: Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: Especially in combination with atelic verbs or verbal pairings, the verb тӱҥалаш [tyŋɑlɑʃ] ‘to begin’ is used as a future auxiliary.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the immediate future?
Comment: Simple past tense 1 forms can, in a structure presumably borrowed from Russian, be used to denote something that is about to happen in the immediate future.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of pluperfect?
Comment: The usual way of expressing this is using the converb of prior action. Also simple past III & IV (distinction between them is evidential), formed by a simple past II form followed by a past-tense form (simple past I and II respectively) of the verb ‘to be’ in the third person singular, are “used to denote an action in the past that preceded another action, or was interrupted by it”.

Name: Can aspect be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment: The particle улмаш [ulmɑʃ] (‘to be’ in simple past II, 3SG) is placed after verbs in sentences in order to “to imply an uncertainty of sorts, or an inference, and in some cases also that an event was unexpected and surprising”, e.g. паша-ште лий-м-ем годым тудо мал-а улмаш [pɑʃɑ-ʃte lij-m-em godəm tudo mɑl-ɑ ulmɑʃ] (work-INE be(come)-PTCP.PASS-PX1SG when 3SG sleep-3SG be.PST2.3SG) 'While I was at work, it turned out s/he was sleeping'. However, there is no grammatical disctinction between evidential and mirative form.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of a desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to irrealis?
Comment: Only periphrastic forms are used.

Name: Are verbs marked in a non-indicative mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Comment: There is a necessitive infinitive with the ending -мыла/-мӹлӓ [-məlɑ/-mə̈læ], and the future-necessitive participle in -шашлык/-шӓшлык [-ʃɑʃlək/-ʃæʃlək].

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Comment: The future-necessitive participle in -шаш [-ʃɑʃ], which prototypically denotes necessity, can in some cases be used in this function.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Comment: There is, however, a suffix -ан [-ɑn] that can be attached to participles (Riese et al. 2019:253) to indicate that they denote possible states rather than real states, e.g. почмо [pot͡ɕmo] 'opened', почман [pot͡ɕmɑn] 'openable'.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there a reflexive conjugation?
Comment: Realized by a highly productive derivational suffix.

Name: Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Can the 3rd person plural verb form and impersonal (passive) verb form be encoded in the same way?
Comment: Probably Russian influence.

Name: Are 2nd singular verb forms commonly used with a generic meaning?
Can an infinitival verb form be used in a directive function?
Comment: Exclamative clauses and in sentences used to express a desire can have bare infinitive predicates (Riese et al. 2019:255). In negation, the nominalization is used in negative existentical clauses to indicate emphatic negation (Riese et al. 2019:379).

Name: Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in the bare infinitive form?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments?
Comment: This typically happens in Mari (only) with causative verb forms. The verbs meaning ‘rain’, ‘snow’ , and ‘blow’ (wind) require a subject.

Name: Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the 3rd person singular forms of the present tense?
Comment: Copula is not needed, e.g. тудо пиалан [tudo piɑlɑn] (3SG happy) 's/he is happy'; it is, however, possible to use  one.

Name: Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the past tense?
Can locative constructions commonly occur without a copula?
Is the same coordinating conjunction commonly used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Does existential negation have a special negator?
Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Comment: The element -ды- [-də- ~ -tə-] is contained in numerous non-finite forms.

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Comment: Realized by a highly productive derivational suffix.

Name: Are there non-finite forms specializing in the relativization of particular core participants, e.g., subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some non-core participants?
Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least some non-core participants but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negative marker?
Comment: While the participle is historically complex (negation element + ending of passive participle), it is treated as a unit in modern language.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject with possessive suffixes?
Are there participles that must agree with the nouns they modify in case and number in all contexts?
Comment: No agreement between modifiers and superordinate nouns in general; participles do not differ from this norm.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Comment: Works with all participles but the active participle.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs?
Comment: The converb in -н, which overwhelmingly forms adverbial forms, forms a very small set of adjectives. This is not a productive process (Riese et al. 2019:269).

Name: Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Comment: The basic word order is SOV. There is no obvious deviation from the norm in the imperative, at least not on a regular basis.

Name: Is it pragmatically neutral to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: “The negation verb and the connegative form are tied to one another tightly in Mari. It is unusual for other elements (e.g., adverbs, pronouns) to occupy the space between them and it is unusual for the word order to change – the connegative form by default follows the negation verb.”

Name: Are there preverbs?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalizations in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalizations in the patient role be encoded like the direct object?
Comment: “Non-finite verbal forms are not inflected for tense and mood, but maintain some verbal properties, for example the argument structure (i.e., they can still have objects)."

Name: Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Comment: Adjectives do not agree with the noun in number in the predicateve position, e.g. нине сӱрет-влак сылне ул-ыт [nine syret-vlɑk səlne ul-ət] (these picture-PL beautiful be-PRS.3PL) 'these pictures are beautiful'.

Name: Is there morphological superlative marking on the property word?
Comment: Analytic formation is used.

Name: Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there adpositions that show a tripartite system?
Is there case compounding?
Comment: “Genitive forms, especially of pronouns, can be used as nominals meaning ‘my one, mine’, ‘your one, yours’, ‘his/her own one, his/hers’, etc. In this case, they can be declined as nouns. Other suffixes, also case suffixes, can follow the genitive suffix.”

Name: Are there morphological cases only used with pronouns?
Comment: The morphologization of certain postpositions (e.g. дек ‘to’) is proceeding faster on demonstrative pronouns: туддек ‘to him/her’ (Riese et al. 2019:136).

Name: Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Comment: The nominative case is used on both occasions, e.g. пӧрт [pørt] 'house' кок пӧрт [kok pørt] 'two houses'.

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals greater than 1?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses indirect object/recipient/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses a terminative meaning?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the absence of a referent (abessive)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses motion along or by a referent (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that expresses goal?
Is there a locative case that expresses location?
Is there a locative case that expresses source?
Comment: The postposition деч [det͡ɕ] ‘from’ could be said to be a de-facto case for which the morphologization is complete; it is only description tradition and orthography that justifies its classification as a postposition rather than a case suffix (Riese et al. 2019:163-164)

Name: Is there case syncretism for goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism for location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Comment: The three postpositions - деке [deke] ‘to’ (Riese et al. 2019:169-170), дене [dene] ‘with’ (Riese et al. 2019:170-172), деч [det͡ɕ] ‘from’ (Riese et al. 2019:172-174) - used similar to external local cases in Finnic languages could be said to be de-facto cases for which the morphologization is complete; it is only description tradition and orthography that justifies its classification as a postposition rather than a case suffix (Riese et al. 2019:163-164).

Name: Are there three or more sets of local cases?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Comment: The postposition дене [dene] ‘with’ could be said to be a de-facto case for which the morphologization is complete; it is only description tradition and orthography that justifies its classification as a postposition rather than a case suffix (Riese et al. 2019:163-164). NB! The so-called comitative case mentioned in Mari grammars and textbooks has a radically different function.

Name: Is there a case that expresses instrument (instrumental), which is different from a case that expresses accompaniment (comitative)?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the result of a change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a case that expresses the result of a change (translative), which is different from a case that expresses a state of being (essive)?
Is there morphological marking dedicated to the expression of equativity?
Comment: “The comparative case is used to express similarity, likeness and can usually be translated into English as ‘like something/someone’, ‘as something/someone’. The object/person with which a noun in the comparative is compared can be used in varying syntactic functions in the sentence: subject, object, etc.”.

Name: Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Comment: The dative is used to mark benefactors.

Name: Is there (in addition to the basic declension) a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use the singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Source: Riese et al. 2019:56; Riese et al. 2014

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Comment: It should be noted that inanimate nouns traditionally did not occur in the genitive at all; inanimate nouns serving as a modification do occur in the nominative (Riese et al. 2019:61-68), e.g. Вена университет [Venɑ universitet] (Vienna.NOM university) University of Vienna’ (see www.mari-language.com).

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Can a 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: “Like the possessive suffix third person singular […] this possessive suffix can beused as a determining element, though its usage is more typical of folklore texts” (Riese et al. 2017:125).

Name: Can a 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: The possessive suffix is used to indicate a rreference to something previously discussed or otherwise salient to the conversation. It is especially commonly used to refer to a subset of a larger whole that is salient.

Name: Is there a human vs. non-human distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with a 3Sg human referent?
Source: Riese et al. 2017:333; Riese et al. 2014

Name: Are there possessive suffixes the position of which can vary in relation to case/number suffixes?
Comment: The “degrees of freedom” depend on the case.

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes the same across the paradigm?
Comment: There are no indications which would show that Cx before Nx is possible.

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Source: Riese et al. 2017:70-72; Riese et al. 2014

Name: Are there different words for younger and older relatives for relations other than siblings?
Source: Riese et al. 2017:70-72; Riese et al. 2014

Name: Is there an animacy distinction for both concepts: 'new/young' and 'old'?
Source: Riese et al. 2017:243; Riese et al. 2014

Name: Is there a distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' depending on whether reference is to weather or the temperature of objects?
Comment: The same word is used in both cases, e.g. шокшо игечe [ʃokʃo iget͡ɕe] 'hot weather' - шокшо вӱд [ʃokʃo vyd] ‘hot water’; йӱштӧ игечe [jyʃtø iget͡ɕe] ‘cold weather’ - йӱштӧ вӱд [jyʃtø vyd] ‘cold water’.

Name: Is there contrastive length for consonants?
Comment: Geminate (long) consonants only occur at morpheme boundaries. Minimal pairs are possible: ныллымше [nəlːəmʃe] ‘fortieth’ (← ныл [nəl] ‘four’ + лу [lu] ‘ten’ + ORD), нылымше [nələmʃe] ‘fourth’ (← ныл [nəl] ‘four’ + ORD).

Name: Is there contrastive length for vowels?
Comment: Reduced vowels are shorter than full vowels, but there is a clear qualitative difference between non-reduced and reduced vowels, so it cannot be reasoned that vowel length alone is distinctive.

Name: Is there a contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Comment: No distinctive vowel length at all.

Name: Is there a contrast in the length of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Comment: No distinctive vowel length at all; geminate consonants only at morpheme boundaries.

Name: Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Comment: However, as final unstressed [e] is reduced, it could be argued that the qualitative difference of this vowel is critical to the phonological disctinction between these words.

Name: Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Comment: In Meadow Mari, suffixes containing full vowels are stressed, but this is in line with the regular stress rules.

Name: Is there fixed primary stress?
Comment: The last full vowel (i.e. anything but [ə] or unstressed/reduced final [e], [o], [ø]) is stressed: пеледыш [peˈledəʃ] ‘flower’, пеледеш [peleˈdeʃ] ‘blossoms’.

Name: Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Comment: Syllable structure has no transparent effect on where stress falls.

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
Comment: The last full vowel (i.e. anything but [ə] or unstressed/reduced final [e], [o], [ø]) is stressed.

Name: Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Comment: Only for labial vowels.

Name: Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Comment: Further palato-velar distinction for labial vowels.

Name: Are there closing diphthongs?
Are there opening diphthongs?
Is there a qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there a high front rounded vowel /y/?
Is there a mid-high front rounded vowel /ø/?
Is there a high back unrounded vowel /ɯ ɨ/?
Is there a mid-high back unrounded vowel /ɤ ɘ/?
Source: Riese et al. 2019:23; Krasnova et al. 2017: 44
Comment: There is however a “mid unrounded central vowel, reduced vowel similarly to the English reduced vowel that is denoted in different ways (alone, lemon, heaven)”, e.g. пыл [pəl] ‘cloud’.

Name: Is there a low back rounded vowel /ɒ/?
Is there a contrast between mid front vowels (/e/ or /ɛ/) and low front vowels (/æ/ or /a/)?
Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: Fairly rare and the effect of a fairly recent loss of reduced vowels that did not happen in all varieties of Mari.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in the syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in the syllable coda?
Are there word-internal intervocalic clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized alveolar consonants?
Comment: The palatal consonants [ʎ] and [ɲ] are frequently mislabelled as palatalized. Palatalized pronunciation under Russian influence and especially in Russian loan words does happen.

Name: Are there palatalized labial and velar consonants?
Comment: Only in Russian loan words among contemporary speakers.

Name: Is there a palatal stop?
Is there a palatal nasal /ɲ/?
Is there a palatal lateral /ʎ/?
Is there a velar nasal /ŋ/?
Is there an alveolar affricate /t͡s/?
Comment: Only in Russian loan words.

Name: Is there a non-alveolar affricate (e.g., /t͡ʃ/, /t͡ɕ/)?
Is there a phonological contrast between an unvoiced alveolar sibilant /s/ and an unvoiced postalveolar sibilant /ʃ/?
Are there voiced plosives (e.g., /b g d/)?
Comment: Historically as allophones of the fricatives /β/, /γ/, /δ/ after homorganic nasals, i.e.: [mb], [ŋg], [nd]. “The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: [β] has generally been replaced by [v]; /b/ is perceived as an independent phoneme; the sounds [γ] and [δ] are mainly realized as [g] and [d] in all positions.”

Name: Is there a glottal stop /ʔ/?
Is there a phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g., /k/ vs. /kʷ/)?
Is there a constraint on the word-initial alveolar trill /r/?
Source: Riese et al. 2019:22; Riese et al. 2017:26
Comment: It is uncommon, but not excluded. There are some words of proto-Uralic origin that have an initial r. There are some varieties in which intial r is preceded by prothetic ə, however, presumably under Chuvash indluence.

Name: Is there a laryngeal fricative /h/?
Is there a voiced velar fricative /ɣ/?
Comment: “Historically, Mari had three voiced fricative phonemes: /β/, /γ/ and /δ/ […] The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: […] the sounds [γ] and [δ] are mainly realized as [g] and [d] in all positions.”

Name: Is there a voiceless velar fricative /x/?
Source: Riese et al. 2019:24; Riese et al. 2017:23
Comment: Only in Russian loan words.

Name: Is there a voiced dental fricative /ð/?
Comment: “Historically, Mari had three voiced fricative phonemes: /β/, /γ/ and /δ/ […] The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: […] the sounds [γ] and [δ] are mainly realized as [g] and [d] in all positions.”

Name: Is there a labio-velar approximant /w/?
Comment: “Historically, Mari had three voiced fricative phonemes: /β/, /γ/ and /δ/ […] The historical pronunciation of these sounds is encountered only rarely today: [β] has generally been replaced by [v]”.

Name: Is there a voiceless labiodental fricative /f/?
Comment: Only in Russian loan words.

Name: Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Comment: There is alternation between [t] and [d] (not marked in orthography; д is used regardless of pronunciation) that has been said to resembles consonant gradation or final consonant devoicing: кид [kit] ‘hand’, кит-лан [kit-lɑn] hand-PX1PL, кид-ем [kid-em] hand-PX1SG. However, the historical explanation here is that [d] was spirantized to [ð] between vowels, and was later replaced by [d] under Russian influence.

Name: Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
